newsitem.title: BELGIUM: FOCUS - U.S. ruffles EU feathers in meat trade deal.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - U.S. ruffles EU feathers in meat trade deal.

text.p: The European Commission said on Friday it may take the U.S. to the World Trade Organisation (WTO) because of Washington's plans to block imports of EU poultry in a row over food safety rules.
The dispute marred a deal in Washington on Wednesday on mutually acceptable inspection rules covering $3 billion of trade annually in red meat, dairy, fish, egg and pet food products.

"We have to wait (and see) exactly what they (the plans) are," Commission chief spokesman Nicholas Van der Pas told a news briefing. "We do not rule out the possibility to go to the WTO because we think that such measures on the basis of the announcements would indeed be unjustified."
On Wednesday, the chief U.S. negotiator Paul Drazek said up to $1.0 million of imports of European poultry products, mainly French chicken pate, would be blocked.

The measure would come as retaliation after the EU on April 1 imposed curbs on imports of $50 million of U.S. poultry, saying that the U.S. method of decontaminating chicken carcasses in chlorinated water posed a threat to consumer health.
In a statement, EU Farm Commissioner Franz Fischler said the agreement, after long and difficult discussions, marked an important step in boosting trade in red meat.
The agreement allows each side to accept the other's meat, dairy and fish products even though they have different inspection methods.
Fischler regretted that the U.S. rejected Brussels' offer of a temporary solution over poultry allowing the U.S. industry to use other chemicals to make chickens safe to eat.

Instead the U.S. was planning to retaliate against EU import curbs by taking unjustified and unfair action against the EU poultry industry even though it was committed to respecting U.S. sanitary measures, he said.
"The U.S. action would be clearly in breach of its WTO sanitary and phytosanitary measures (SPS) obligations, and the EC would have to consider the appropriate action to be taken," Fischler added.
Although further talks are planned, Commission officials said no date had been fixed and did not foresee any early settlement.
